bibl.title: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, July 20, 1942

div1.p: Wood discusses the upcoming publication of her book. Truby visited recently and gave her more information on the yellow fever experiments. She inquires if Hench knows who first volunteered for the experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, July 20, 1942
div1.p:
The Army must think a lot of you, even to let you organize
your own staff. It sounds swell.

You will be interested to learn that the Junior Literary
Guild, which is an outfit like the Book of the Month Club,
or the Literary Guild, only for children, has taken Reed
for one of its books. They don't want it, however, until
spring, so that holds up publication again. More dough,
though, eventually.

General Truby was in Philadelphia recently, and came to see
me. He says positively that Reed was on to mosquitoes be-
fore the Pinar del Rio episode and had seen Finlay before
it, too, and he had a lot of circumstantial details to sup-
port this recollection. He also thought it likely that Reed
knew of Carter's paper, since Reed and Carter were friends,
without Lazear's drawing it to his notice. Another thing he
said supported a conclusion I had arrived at: that Kissinger
was the first volunteer, and that Moran followed after some
very short interval. I had thought this likely, since Kissin-
ger was given the first bite - an “honor” which would likely
have been conferred on the first volunteer (unless it had some-
thing to do with length of quarantine), and since it was of
Kissinger that Reed made that rather fulsome remark about moral
courage. I am thinking seriously of revising my ms to have
Kissinger the first volunteer, if you should agree that this
conclusion is probably the correct one. It does seem silly to
perpetuate what you know to be error, and I'd like to get it
down right. If you could take time to tell me yes you agree
or no you don't, I'd appreciate it a lot.

I hope I am right today in thinking of you in Colorado Springs.
It is simply stifling here, and I should like to think that at
least one person I know is cool.
